name: Pottery Studio & Kiln

mappings.label: Clay Selection
mappings.description: The checkpoint (model weights) becomes the clay material itself. Selecting a checkpoint is like choosing a specific clay body — each has different properties that will influence the final piece. The metaphor works because models are pre-trained materials that determine aesthetic output, just as clay type determines pottery characteristics. Weakness: clay selection is less visually obvious than a recipe or blueprint, so some users may need explanation of why this choice matters.

facadeControls.label: Clay Type
facadeControls.rationale: Dropdown naturally represents selecting from a palette of available materials. User can see available options and understand they're choosing a fundamental material.

mappings.assetPrompt: Pottery studio shelf with stacked clay blocks in earth tones (terracotta, stoneware, porcelain white), warm studio lighting, front view, 256x256

mappings.label: Envisioned Form
mappings.description: Positive text prompt becomes the potter's detailed vision — what they want to create. Text input remains explicitly textual (the artist writes down their intent), which preserves full expressive capability. This is strong because text prompts ARE instructions/descriptions, just like a potter's mental image or written notes. The mapping keeps text in its native form.

facadeControls.label: What you want to create
facadeControls.rationale: Text area lets users type their full creative vision naturally. In pottery metaphor, this is the artist writing or describing their desired form, glaze, style.

mappings.assetPrompt: Potter's sketchbook open to a detailed pencil drawing of a ceramic vessel with annotations, warm lighting, close-up 256x256

mappings.label: What to Avoid
mappings.description: Negative text prompt becomes the potter's notes on what NOT to create — flaws, styles, or elements to avoid. Text remains textual and explicit. This preserves the refinement aspect of creative work (knowing what you don't want is as important as knowing what you do). Parallel to positive prompt in structure and handling.

facadeControls.label: What to avoid
facadeControls.rationale: Text area for exclusions — things the potter wants to prevent. Natural in creative process where 'avoid cracks, avoid asymmetry' is common language.

mappings.assetPrompt: Potter's rough notes with crossed-out sketches and written 'NO' annotations on margins, charcoal pencil style, 256x256

mappings.label: Canvas Size Setup
mappings.description: Empty latent space becomes the wheel prepared with centered clay, ready to be thrown. Setting width/height/batch_size is like preparing the wheel with clay of a specific amount and mounting it. The metaphor works because this is a preparatory stage that defines the scale of work to come. Weakness: latent space is abstract mathematical space, and 'prepared clay on wheel' only partially captures this (real pottery is continuous, latent space is discrete grid).

facadeControls.label: Canvas Width
facadeControls.rationale: Slider for wheel radius/clay mass. Users intuitively understand more clay = larger piece. Maps to latent dimensions.

facadeControls.label: Canvas Height
facadeControls.rationale: Second dimension slider. Together with width, defines the rectangular canvas size.

facadeControls.label: Batch Count
facadeControls.rationale: How many pieces to throw at once. Multiple batches = multiple wheels spinning in parallel.

mappings.assetPrompt: Pottery wheel mounted with centered clay, viewed from above, spinning motion lines, studio lighting, earth tone palette, 256x256

mappings.label: Creation Chamber
mappings.description: The diffusion sampling becomes the kiln — a controlled environment where clay transforms through heat and time into finished ceramics. You feed in visions (prompts), raw material (latent), and parameters control how the transformation proceeds. This is the core creative step. Strong mapping: kiln firing IS iterative transformation (steps = firing cycles); temperature/conditions control output quality (CFG = kiln intensity); randomness in pottery firing (seed = natural clay variations). Weakness: actual diffusion is mathematical iterative denoising, while kiln firing is physical/chemical — the analogy breaks if examined too closely.

facadeControls.label: Clay Variation Seed
facadeControls.rationale: Slider with numeric input. In pottery, natural clay has slight variations that create uniqueness. Seed controls the random variations in diffusion — same clay body, slightly different results each time.

facadeControls.label: Firing Duration (Steps)
facadeControls.rationale: Slider representing time/iterations. More steps = longer kiln firing = more refinement of the form. 20 steps = brief firing, 50 steps = full lengthy kiln process. Intuitive in pottery context.

facadeControls.label: Kiln Intensity (Guidance)
facadeControls.rationale: How strongly the kiln 'enforces' the vision. Low intensity = loose firing, piece may vary. High intensity = strict control, piece follows vision closely. Maps CFG (classifier-free guidance) to kiln temperature/conditions intensity.

facadeControls.label: Firing Method
facadeControls.rationale: Different sampling algorithms (Euler, DPM, etc.) are like different kiln firing schedules — fast ramp-up vs slow, reducing atmosphere vs oxidizing. Each method has different characteristics.

facadeControls.label: Temperature Curve
facadeControls.rationale: Scheduler controls the noise reduction pace (linear vs exponential curve). In kiln metaphor, this is the temperature ramp schedule — how quickly heat increases/decreases.

mappings.assetPrompt: Cross-section view of a ceramic kiln glowing red-orange inside, clay vessels visible inside being transformed by heat, flames, glowing coils, 256x256

mappings.label: Finishing Process
mappings.description: VAE decode (converting latent space to image space) becomes the cooling and finishing stage — the piece comes out of the kiln hot, is cooled carefully, then glazed/finished. The abstract mathematical latent representation becomes a viewable ceramic surface. Weakness: VAE decode is actually an encoding/decoding step (mathematical compression), not physical finishing — the metaphor is somewhat loose here. However, it maintains the sequence naturally.
mappings.assetPrompt: Potter removing a finished ceramic vessel from kiln with tongs, smoke rising, glowing pottery being cooled, workshop background, 256x256

mappings.label: Presentation & Archiving
mappings.description: Saving the final image becomes cataloging the finished piece in the pottery gallery — documenting it for the world to see. The filename becomes the piece label/name in the catalog. This completes the creative cycle: raw material → envisioning → creation → finishing → sharing. Strong because it mirrors real pottery workflows (artists document and display finished work).

facadeControls.label: Piece Name/ID
facadeControls.rationale: Text field for naming the work. Just as potters label their pieces ('Vase 2024-A'), users name their outputs for organizational clarity.

mappings.assetPrompt: Gallery shelf displaying finished ceramic pieces, well-lit with warm spotlights, labeled plaques under each vessel, professional gallery setting, 256x256

threadStyle.metaphor: Flows represent: (1) clay/material flowing from source through the artist's creative process, (2) the artist's written vision flowing into the kiln, (3) prepared canvas flowing in, (4) all converging into the kiln transformation, (5) finished ceramic piece flowing to cooling/finishing, then to gallery.

waveMetaphor: Data tokens moving through this workflow are like clay particles flowing: they start as raw clay (model), get shaped by the artist's vision (text prompts), are placed on the wheel (latent prep), then transformed through the kiln's heat (diffusion steps), cooled into final form (VAE decode), and cataloged in the gallery (saved image). Each stage the data becomes more refined and organized.
sceneDescription: An aerial view of a pottery studio-kiln complex: on the left, clay storage shelves; in the center-left, a potter's workbench with vision sketches; center, a large glowing kiln with multiple wheels of prepared clay; right side, cooling racks with finished pieces; far right, gallery display shelves with labeled pieces. Warm earth-tone lighting, clay dust floating in light rays, wooden workbenches, terracotta pots scattered throughout. The entire workflow flows left-to-right: material selection → envisioning → preparation → creation → finishing → display.
aiVocabulary: When narrating this workflow, describe it as a pottery creation process: 'You select a clay body (checkpoint), envision what you want to create (positive prompt) and what to avoid (negative prompt), prepare your canvas by centering clay on the wheel (latent image), then fire it in the kiln with specific conditions (KSampler with steps, CFG, seed controlling the creation process). The piece cools and is glazed/finished (VAE decode), then cataloged in your studio gallery (save image). Higher steps mean longer, more refined firing. Higher CFG means stricter adherence to your artistic vision. Different samplers are like different firing schedules. The seed introduces natural variations like real clay does.'

attributeScores.rationale: Dropdown is intuitive for selecting from a palette of materials. Clay selection clearly affects final output (color, texture), directly paralleling how model checkpoints determine aesthetic. Users understand 'choosing material' naturally.

mappingScores.rationale: Clay source is a strong metaphorical anchor. Models are pre-trained weights that determine output characteristics, exactly like clay body determines ceramic properties. Dropdown control is natural. Weakness: less immediately obvious than recipe or blueprint metaphors, but gains authenticity in craft context.

attributeScores.rationale: Text input remains explicitly textual — this is critical. Potter writes down or describes their intended form. Text is the native medium for prompts; no abstraction loses information. Users understand 'write what you want' immediately.

mappingScores.rationale: Excellent mapping. Text prompts ARE descriptions/instructions, and a pottery studio vision is exactly that. No forced abstraction. Text remains fully legible and editable. This is one of the metaphor's strongest points.

attributeScores.rationale: Negative prompts become refinement notes (what NOT to create). Natural in pottery — artists regularly note 'avoid cracks', 'no asymmetry', 'avoid thick walls'. Text is explicit. Slightly less intuitive than positive prompt (people more naturally focus on what they want), but still very strong.

mappingScores.rationale: Strong secondary mapping. Maintains textual explicitness. Parallel structure to positive prompt aids understanding. In creative workflows, exclusion is as important as inclusion.

attributeScores.rationale: Slider for wheel size/clay mass. Users understand 'more clay = larger piece'. But latent dimensions (256x256 vs 512x512) are discrete grid points, not continuous clay — partially truthful.
Second dimension. Combined with width, forms aspect ratio. In pottery, height and width are continuous properties; here they're discrete tokens. Functional but not perfectly truthful.
Multiple wheels spinning in parallel is intuitive for batch processing. Users understand 'more wheels = more pieces made at once'. Truthful — batch_size directly maps to parallel processing.

mappingScores.rationale: Moderate mapping. Wheel preparation is a plausible metaphor for latent space setup, but latent space is abstract mathematical construct, and pottery clay is physical. The metaphor works for user understanding (understand output size), but breaks if examined deeply. Not a critical weakness because latent space can be abstracted in many workflows.

attributeScores.rationale: Seed as natural clay variations is intuitive — same clay body creates slightly different pots due to natural variation. Truthful: seed controls stochastic variation in diffusion. Slightly abstract (users may not understand seed's actual computational role).

Steps as firing duration is excellent. More time = more refinement. Users understand 'longer kiln time = better quality piece'. Truthful: more steps = more diffusion iterations = refined image. Range (1-50) maps intuitively to kiln duration perception.

CFG (classifier-free guidance) as kiln intensity/temperature is somewhat forced. It controls how strictly diffusion follows prompts, like kiln controls transform. But CFG is algorithmic guidance, not physical intensity — metaphor partially breaks. Still intuitive for basic understanding (higher = stricter control).

Different samplers (Euler, DPM, etc.) as different firing schedules is creative but abstract. Users won't intuitively understand what 'DPM++ 2M' means as a 'firing schedule'. Truthful-ish: different samplers do produce different results, like different schedules. Weak point in this metaphor.

Scheduler as temperature curve is quite abstract. The scheduler controls noise schedule pacing — exponential vs linear. This is deeply mathematical and doesn't clearly map to pottery. Weakest control in this mapping. Most users won't understand what this does in pottery terms.

mappingScores.rationale: Core element is strong (kiln = transformation chamber), but facade controls are mixed. Steps and seed are excellent; sampler and scheduler controls are weak abstractions. Overall the kiln metaphor captures the core idea (iterative refinement through multiple 'firings') but struggles with advanced parameters. For beginner/intermediate users, sufficient; for power users, the metaphor breaks down on advanced controls.

Weak mapping. VAE decode is actually an encoding/decoding mathematical operation (compressing/decompressing in latent space). 'Cooling and glazing' is physically intuitive but technically inaccurate. The piece going from hot kiln to finished ceramic is appealing narratively but misrepresents what VAE actually does. However, the sequence (kiln → cooling → finished piece) maintains workflow intuition. Users won't understand what VAE actually does from this metaphor, but they'll understand 'after creation comes finishing'.

attributeScores.rationale: Text field for naming artwork is natural. Potters name their pieces; photographers name their prints. Users understand 'give it a name for organizing your work'. Truthful: filename_prefix directly controls saved file naming.

mappingScores.rationale: Good closing element. Gallery/catalog metaphor completes the creative cycle and mirrors real pottery workflows. Text field for naming is intuitive. Weakness: the actual output is a digital image file, not a physical pottery piece on display, so slight mismatch in finality.

ioAnalysis.rationale: Text input handling is excellent (text remains explicitly textual in pottery vision). Model handling is strong (clay source metaphor is clear). Intermediate handling is weak: latent space becomes 'prepared clay on wheel' (loose abstraction) and VAE becomes 'cooling/glazing' (technically inaccurate but narratively useful). Final output handling is adequate: image becomes 'finished ceramic piece' — close but user receives a digital image file, not physical pottery. Overall pipeline maintains user understanding while simplifying abstractions.

scores.rationale: The Pottery Studio metaphor scores well on explanatory power (7.4) because it uses a familiar craft context that most people have basic familiarity with. Text input handling is excellent (9/10) — prompts remain textual vision notes. Model handling is strong (8/10) — clay source is intuitive. However, truthfulness suffers (6.8) due to weak intermediate mappings: latent space as 'prepared clay' is loose (6.5/10 elementFit), and VAE decode as 'cooling/glazing' misrepresents the actual mathematical operation (5.5/10 elementFit). The KSampler kiln metaphor is strong for steps (8/10) and seed (7/10) but breaks on sampler_name (6/10) and scheduler (5/10) controls — advanced parameters don't map intuitively. Completeness is good (8.0) — all major knots have mappings and key parameters have controls. Intuitive interaction is solid (7.2) — beginning-to-intermediate users will understand the workflow naturally, though power users will find sampler/scheduler controls unhelpful. Fractal consistency is moderate (6.5) — clay metaphor is consistent, kiln metaphor is consistent, but VAE decode breaks the craft metaphor. Overall 7.2 reflects a solid, usable metaphor with good narrative arc and text-handling clarity, but with acknowledged gaps in abstract parameter representation and technical accuracy on intermediate steps. Strengths: text prompts stay textual, familiar craft domain, intuitive controls for core parameters (steps, seed, batch). Weaknesses: sampler/scheduler controls unintuitive, VAE mapping is weak, latent space abstraction loose, final output mismatch (digital file vs physical piece).
